intro:
Random Coal-fired Industrialist

Currently burning 193gal of diesel fuel

post.body: So this appears to be like Facebook or something for ZeroNet. I haven't a damned clue what I'm doing here.
Who runs ZeroMe, anyway? Is it the developers of Zeronet? And how do you get into contact with them for improvement ideas and bug reports? I feel like this site needs some more details.

ZeroName needs a search feature too, it's fairly difficult to find sites that aren't built in to the homepage. 0list could use a search too. I'd just like to explore, but it's fairly difficult to navigate just for casual browsing.
BundleStars is doing a mystery steam key giveaway! Enter here -> https://wn.nr/yKkdcM

I started a blog for shits and giggles, you can check it out here: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1P4aD4C9emPfhTksXgw1svVaaEKTd82tC5/

I'm not planning to do much more than rant about broken equipment, but feel free to look at your leisure.
Someone send me a ZeroMail at my zeroid address, I'm not even sure the service is working right, the echobot isn't replying.

I wonder how well the ZeroNet system would work on slower connections, like 2G data or a 56K modem. The nature of downloading and caching each site would make browsing actually manageable. You obviously couldn't upload or seed anything, but I'm not even sure it would be fast enough to sync anything in a reasonable amount of time. You might be stuck with 5min sync delays, assuming the connection didn't just do a timeout from the start, but it'd be usable if you don't have anything else. 

Now I wish I had a landline or wireless modem left to test this with. Damn progress, always getting in the way of curiosity.

comment.body: @Gallium: Yea, I do too. It also updates faster than Twitter, at least in my case.
@Kaffie: Yea, I just got pointed to Kaffiene in a ZeroTalk thread. It's bookmarked and I'm seeding, it's exactly what I was looking for.
@HrnekBezucha: I can't open a port so I'm seeding on TOR. You'll probably need a direct connection to get the first copy.

@Jayofthezero: Thanks! I've been meaning to talk with my ISP about possibly getting a direct Internet connection (instead of the firewalled/subnetted crap they have now) but I doubt they'll do anything. They barely keep their service running at decent rates.
Thanks both of ya - I got em. Must be a problem with the echobot then.

I've used C++ before, but only as a minor side project. I can do math, print statements and if/else, but that's about it. 

I also suck at debugging. Took me four hours to fix a compiler error that occurred due to a missing semicolon.
@Quadrangle: I've tried, but my router won't cap below 500kbps. I might dig out my Tomato flashed router for this project, assuming it'll quit rebooting every 5 minutes.

@Gallium: You don't have to, I was just in it for curiosity's sake. A friend has a cabin out in the boondocks with a wired line, if I'm ever out at his place sometime I might try it out. 

I was really just wondering for some of our third world friends, where slower connections (and/or dialup) is *the* only option. Being able to cache sites locally and only update periodically would make the Net much more accessible.
